awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Ancestral reconstruction of plasticity along environmental gradients: tracing the pathways to ecological specialization
awd_abstract_narration:
Ecological specialization is the engine generating biological diversity. But why do species become specialists on a particular resource or set of conditions rather than expand their niches to become more generalized, incorporating both old and new resources? How does the degree to which species are specialized in their ecological niche predict their geographic range and climatic tolerances? Is the ability to tolerate a large range of environmental and resource conditions (i.e., to be a generalist) a trait that is shared over evolutionary time by species? This project uses cutting edge analytical techniques to map the resilience of multiple plant species onto the pattern of their evolutionary relationships. This will allow researchers to explore how species tolerance to environmental change evolves across related species, whether tolerance to a range of experimental environments predicts the degree to which species are specialized in their current ecological niches, and whether current tolerance can predict species' responses to future changes in the climate. This project also advances education and diversity by training underrepresented groups of students. 

This project combines contemporary (ecological experiments/observations) with historical (phylogenetic) approaches to disentangle intrinsic and extrinsic forces driving ecological specialization. Ancestral trait reconstruction of multivariate parameters describing norms of reactions will be completed on multiple plant species. Fitness, in addition to leaf physiology and other plant traits, will be measured in 18 Streptanthoid species grown in environmental treatments that represent gradients in water availability and leaf herbivory. Once completed this project will help us understand how the evolution of plasticity and competitive response relates to specialization. In addition, new methodological approaches should contribute to the study of these questions in a variety of systems across the tree of life. Graduate students from underrepresented groups will contribute directly to this research.

por.por_cntn:
It is valuable to understand how the abilities of individuals to withstand stress scale up to predict the habitats and geographic ranges they live in as a whole. In California's Mediterranean habitats, there are rains that begin in the fall, and stop in the spring until the following fall. Climate in California has been getting drier over the last 30 years, with fall rains starting later and dropping less water than in the past. In this project, we asked how 11 species of wildflower responded to variable water availability. In addition, we asked whether there are costs or trade-offs in the ability to handle water stress in terms of overall reproduction.  Using a group of species in the mustard family (same as broccoli family), we grew plants for all 11 species under experimental water availabilities that ranged from half of the yearly rainfall of the driest species' collection site to 50% more than mean rainfall of the wettest year of the wettest species' collection site.  We found that species with individuals that could reproduce at very low water levels were highly drought adapted, but were unable to keep reproducing if additional water was provided throughout the season (as in later rainfall events in California). In contrast, species that could capitalize on later rainfall and keep reproducing were unable to reproduce at the lowest water levels. This trade-off was found across 11 species whose ranges together spanned from the southern deserts of California to northern California and the Oregon border. Drought -tolerant species flowered earlier and grew faster, while species that could respond to more ample water had delayed flowering. 

It is also interesting to consider how much any single individual can tolerate a range of water availability and still reproduce, and whether such an ability can predict range-wide attributes of the species.  In the same experiment as above, we showed that the extent of water availability over which individual families could reproduce was correlated with the size of the geographic range of the species as whole. In other words, individuals of similar genotypes (family members)  that could produce fruits over a large degree of water availability came from species that had large geographic ranges and spanned a range of natural water availability. Conversely, individuals that could only reproduce over a small range of water availability came from species that had smaller geographic ranges and occupied a smaller climate niche. There was, however, a cost to being able to tolerate a wide range of water conditions: individuals from species specialized on a narrow band of water availability tended to have greater maximum fitness  than species that were able to reproduce across a wider range of conditions. In other words, there was a cost to being broadly tolerant of a range of water conditions in terms of the maximum reproduction at any water level.

Our results show that species have diverged in their strategies for dealing with variable, low water. Desert species grow fast and reproduce even under very dry conditions, but cannot keep reproducing when simulated rain continued later in the season. In contrast, more northern species with wetter habitats  were unable to survive or reproduce at the lowest water availability, but they were able to keep growing with an extended rainy season. Individual genotypes with the ability to reproduce across a range of water availability experienced a cost in having lower maximum fitness than species with individuals that had a narrower range of water tolerance. These diverged strategies to dealing with erratic rainfall will mean that some species could be expected to suffer more than others under changing climate and rainfall patterns, and we could predict which would be most vulnerable for a given set of rainfall trends.
